title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #489: Gaps Between B-Free Numbers**

For sparse A, does lim (1/x)Σ(b_{i+1}-b_i)² exist for A-free numbers?

**Status: OPEN** (in general)

Squarefree case (A = prime squares) is solved.
mathContext: This connects number theory, sieve methods, and gap distributions in sequences defined by divisibility conditions.

title: Sparse Set
content:
**IsSparse:**

A set A is sparse if |A ∩ [1,x]| = o(x^{1/2}).

This means A grows slower than √x - the critical threshold for this problem.

title: B-Free Numbers
Gap Function
content:
**gap:**

g_i = b_{i+1} - b_i

The gap between consecutive B-free numbers.

title: Normalized Gap Statistic
content:
**normalizedGapStatistic:**

(1/x) Σ_{b_i<x} (b_{i+1} - b_i)²

The second moment of gaps, normalized by x.

title: Limit Existence
content:
**LimitExists:**

Does lim_{x→∞} (1/x)Σ(gap)² exist?

This is the main question - does the second moment of gaps converge?

title: Erdős Conjecture
content:
**ErdosConjecture:**

For ALL sparse A, the limit exists.

This is the general open question.

title: Prime Squares
Squarefree Case Solved
content:
**erdos_squarefree_limit:**

For A = prime squares (B = squarefree numbers), the limit EXISTS.

This was proved by Erdős - the known special case.

title: Squarefree Density
content:
**squarefree_density:**

Density of squarefree numbers is 6/π² ≈ 0.6079.

This is a classical result in analytic number theory.

title: K-Free Numbers
content:
**IsKFree:**

k-free numbers are not divisible by any k-th power > 1.

Squarefree = 2-free, cubefree = 3-free, etc.

title: Why Sparseness?
content:
**sparseness_necessity:**

The condition |A ∩ [1,x]| = o(√x) ensures B has positive density.

If A is too dense, B could have density 0, making gaps infinite.

title: Erdős Problem #489: OPEN
content:
**erdos_489:**

Status: OPEN (in general)

Squarefree case solved, general case remains open.

title: State of Knowledge
content:
**erdos_489_summary:**

1. **Squarefree case:** SOLVED (limit exists)
2. **General sparse A:** OPEN

The second moment of gaps converges for squarefree numbers.
